text:
Now, to our guest today, Andy. He's a professor both at the
GSB and in Political Science.

And yeah, he's been a
co-director of SIEPR

and the center for polarization
research, Polarization Lab.

And also, he'll be teaching a
course next quarter on, well,

DAOs, but like blockchain
governments more generally, which
will be cross-listed across a whole bunch of
different schools for probably

the first time ever. So yeah, he'll be he'll be
telling you a little bit more about that as well.

And you can see his website. But yeah, I'll let
you take it away. Great.

Thank you. Yeah. Yeah, just briefly before
I get into my material, we are teaching a new class on
blockchain governance and mostly

about DAOS, how they work,
practical questions about DAOs,

view from social science
and view from law, as well as how to
actually build them. And so this will be
co-taught between me

coming from the
business school, which is why it's a GSB-listed class,
Dan Bohen in the CS Department

and Jeff Strnad
in the Law School. So it'll be a pretty cool,
exciting cross-Stanford class

about blockchain governance. And I hope people will take it. And yeah, don't
hesitate to email me if you have any
questions about it.

It's supposed to be
open to everyone. No prereqs. Should be super fun. Cool. I'm going to dive in.

Please interrupt me at any
time if anything's not clear or if you just have
questions, I purposefully

made the number of
slides pretty small. I'm usually pretty
succinct person. I'm relatively confident
I'll get through everything.

So please don't hesitate
to interrupt at any time, and I gather. There's a mic you can use if
you want to be on the video.

which is relevant for some of
what I'm going to talk about. And what I want to talk
about today is governance.

So my background, as we just
said is, from Political Science. I've historically
mostly studied how

you design constitutions
systems of government for the real world. But over the last
five years, I've

spent more and more of my
time in the digital world, trying to understand how we
could write constitutions

or design systems of
governance for different kinds of online communities
or platforms.

And so when I say
governance, what I mean is, the system that
determines who has the power

to make decisions
and the process by which they make
those decisions. It's really central to
a lot of human society

to decide how you're
going to do those things, and it affects
kind of everything. And the point I
want to make just

to motivate everything
I'm going to talk about today is that
web3 or crypto. A lot of the
motivation, essentially,

all of the motivation has
something to do with governance. If you look at what people say
about web3 s and blockchain,

the whole point is it's supposed
to be the system for making strong commitments,
this idea like

as Tim Roughgarden puts it
right a computer in the sky that no one owns. And you can use that computer to
make commitments to one another.

You can create property rights,
strong, enforceable contracts, and so forth. And the whole justification for
why we're interested in that

has something to do with
this idea of distributing out power or decentralizing power,
whatever you want to call it.

And so it really is
about governance. And if we can get
governance to work well,

then I think there's
a huge amount of promise in this whole space. But, of course, what
we've seen to date is that getting
governance to work well

is actually super, super hard. And we all know that
from our own experience in the real world. It's very hard to point to
anywhere in the real world,

where you're like,
yeah, it's super easy to solve that collective
choice problem. Some societies, some cities,
some countries, some clubs

seem to be better
at it than others, but it's super, super
hard everywhere. And so it shouldn't
be that surprising

that we're still in the early
stages of figuring this out for web3, too. And so that's what I
want to talk about today,

is what we've seen so far
in terms of governance in web3, what some
of the key problems are, some examples of how
different projects are dealing

with this, and so forth. And I'm going to be
drawing largely here, I'll say, from my
experience of working

with a bunch of
different DAO projects, trying to understand
their governance problems,

and trying to draw
analogies from what I've seen in the physical world
to design new ways of doing

governance for web3. So let me just, on that point,
just tell you very quickly

something I'm sure you probably
all already have a sense of, which is that what's going on in
crypto and on the internet more

generally is a very interesting
and a logical extension of what's come before. So sometimes,
you'll see rhetoric

about how this is all
super new and different. And in some ways,
of course, it is. But it's also worth reflecting
on and thinking about the fact

that we can probably
learn a lot from what's happened before because a lot of
the same challenges and problems have come up.

So let me give you 30
seconds of background on corporate governance and
30 seconds of backgrounds on democracy.

There's a lot of
other people on campus you could go very deep
on these topics with. Corporate governance.

We start out maybe
600, 700 years ago. People want to
invest in projects. They want to launch a ship
to go somewhere or something,

and maybe find
something worth money. At first, maybe
you're one investor.

You fund the whole
thing yourself. You pay attention to it. It goes well, whatever. Then over time,
you're like, hmm,

maybe I should invest
in a bunch of these. And then a bunch of other
people are like, I should also invest in these. Now, suddenly, you each have a
portfolio of these investments,

and you can't spend all
your time monitoring it. You're invested in
a bunch of things, so are a lot of other people.

You start to think,
I'm too busy. And also, I'm just
one of 100 people who invested in this thing.

Why should I pay
any attention to it? And things start to go wrong. People's money gets stolen.

Might sound familiar. Some things we've heard
about here recently. So what do you do?

Well, we invent
this whole apparatus to monitor the investments and
to try to make them go well,

and to prevent theft, and to
prevent other kinds of mistakes. And what does that
structure look like? Well, we have shareholders
that vote on things.

But we don't expect shareholders
to vote on everything because it's too hard to ask
them to vote on everything. They don't show up to do it.

They don't know what
they need to do it, and they're just one of 100
or thousands of shareholders. So why should they learn?

So what do we do instead? We have a board. We have a board
of a small number of people, who are paid
to monitor on our behalf,

to be our agents monitoring
this corporation. That's the core insight, to some
extent, of corporate governance.

There's a lot of
other things too. But that's like a really
key part of it, the idea that we elect a board that
represents us as shareholders

to monitor the investment. That's exactly what we see to
some extent going on in Dallas

today. We have this sort of
like the exact same idea that when there were
just a couple of us,

we could vote on everything. And then Dallas
started to get bigger, and more people entered them. And it started to become
impractical really, really

quickly. And we started to see a
lot of things go wrong. And now, one of
the things you'll

see a lot in the DAO
space is people saying, hmm, maybe there
should be a council, or maybe there should
be a group of delegates

that oversee these things
for us on a regular basis. And maybe we should pay them. And so I just want to point
out there's a lot of parallels

here to corporate governance. Obviously, there's also a lot
of parallels to democracy.

The exact same kind of
thing happened in democracy. When it's 10 or 15 people
in a settlement together,

you can talk everything
out and just figure it out. And then as it starts to scale,
it gets harder to do that.

And you might have a similar
calculus to what I described with corporate governance. Why should I pay
attention to everything?

I have other stuff I have to
do, and there's 500 people here. Can't some of them do it? I'm not going to weigh in it.

Wouldn't matter
if I did anyways. I'm just one person. And so democracy goes through
the exact same type of evolution

prior to corporate governance. And they come up with very
similar set of solutions. And this is where
corporate governance

got a lot of their ideas from. We started electing
representatives, whose full-time
job was to monitor

the goings on of
government on our behalf and to steer it in directions
we want it to go in. Obviously, it doesn't work
smoothly all the time.

Maybe an understatement. But it's a lot better than
the alternative, which is so-called direct
democracy, which

you won't see any
society on Earth use for any sustainable
amount of time because it simply doesn't work. And that's what DAOs are
figuring out right now.

They've already pretty
much figured it out. It just doesn't work. So what can you do instead? That's what I want
to talk about today,

is like what are DAO doing? How does it borrow
from these histories? But how is it new and different? And I just want to say
as a political scientist,

it's a crazy exciting
time because there really should be something new here.

The technology
really is different. So we're not going to
completely reinvent the wheel. There's a lot we can borrow,
but there are new things here

that are different. We can vote in different ways. We can assign out power
in different ways. We can meet on
different frequencies.

We can make different
types of decisions. Thanks to technology. So that's what I'm going
to talk about today.

The way I want to structure
this talk is along the lines of the meetings
that I have with projects so

that if you're thinking
of starting a project, you're thinking of working
with a project, hopefully, this will be right on point
for the kinds of things

you should be thinking about. And I want to organize
that whole thing around one question, which
is when you, let's say,

want to build a DAO, what do you
want governance to do for you? And the reason I want to frame
it this way is sometimes,

we have this tendency in life--
it's just natural in a lot of domains-- to start with the tool and
then decide what it's for.

And this definitely
happens sometimes in web3. I'm sure we've all experienced
this at some point. And so someone might just say,
I need to have governance.

I don't know why. But it's like a cool thing
in web3, and so I need it. And obviously,
that is not the way

to figure out exactly how to
design something for success. And so what you
really want to do is start with what is the
goal you're trying to solve,

because depending on that
goal, you might actually arrive at different structures. And so that's why it's
not always useful.

Sometimes you'll see
blog posts or tweets in the space that are like,
this is the way governance
should work. It should be all token voting. It should be no token voting.

Both could be right answers
for different use cases. And so you have to start
with the motivation. What are you trying to
accomplish with your governance

structure? There's surely a lot of
potential answers to that, and I don't want to
pretend to have all of them

or even most of them. So I'm just going to hit on
three possible justifications

for DAO governance that
I have seen come up and that I think
also make sense,

but this is not meant to
be an exhaustive list. But those three things that
I'm going to go through in some detail
are-- you might want

to set up decentralized
governance so that your protocol
is censorship-resistant so that there's no single point
of failure or single person,

or entity that can be gone
after in various ways. You might want to do it
to create user demand.

Sometimes we see these cases,
where people are actually very excited about the chance
to be part of a project that

is collectively governed. So that's like a completely
different motivation from the first. And the third is this broader
idea of using it to build trust.

If this is a
long-run project, you want people to build on
top of your protocol. You want people to come and
work with you, partner with you

in different ways. To be able to say this is
governed by the community might be helpful in
creating those partnerships

and in building
that long-run trust. So those are three common
motivations I see all of which

draw on historical
experiences and research that I'll talk a
little bit about. Obviously, there are downsides
to building out governance

It's also like a
super blunt instrument with a lot of downsides. So we know. We've probably all experienced
it in various ways.

It's slow, prone to conflict. If participation is low, it's
very prone to interest group

capture, which we see in DAO
governance from time to time, and so forth. You would never
design a smartphone

through a democratic process. And so the question
is, where do you want to use this incredibly
powerful but incredibly

complicated tool? You don't want to
use it everywhere. No one uses it everywhere. You want to use it where
the value to using it far

exceeds these costs. So that's what we're
going to think about. So I'm going to run
through these three goals

and tell you a little bit
about why they make sense, and give you some
examples of projects

that I think fit these
goals in different ways. So the first one is
this very popular phrase

"resisting censorship,"
or it could mean a lot of different things. But the basic idea is that
right a big promise of web3

is that you can create these
long-lived protocols, and no one can mess with them,
in some sense.

And so some of that is
baked in a lot of that, perhaps, is baked
into blockchain. And you don't need to add
governance to your project

to enjoy the benefits that are
just baked into blockchain, the immutability and so forth.

However, it's basically
impossible, as far as I know. Maybe someone can can
tell me otherwise.

As far as I can see,
there is essentially no important protocol or
open-source software project

more generally, where there's
never any new decision that has to be made.

At a minimum, the
world changes, and you have to decide something about
how to update the protocol,

or change it in some way. But then there's
a much broader set of things that also
tends to happen. It tends to be that there needs
to be strategic decisions made.

What's the future
vision of this project? Sometimes, revenue comes in.

What are you going to
do with the treasury? Those are all
governance decisions that go beyond something that
can be just ossified and made

unchanging. And so that's where
governance comes in, where decisions have to be made.

And what people have
discovered over time in web3 is that that could
be an area, where

using the tools of
democracy is valuable, if you want to remain in this
censorship-resistant world

and you want to be able to
say this is a democratically governed project. Anonymous entities anywhere in
the world can join this project

and be part of its governance. No one is in charge. And that can be quite
valuable for some projects.

And that's a tool that's
something that democracy might be able to help us with. However, to do that, obviously,
democracy has to work.

And one of the challenges
here that we've seen so far, which is completely unsurprising
if you've spent time

in other types of
democratic systems, is that it's hard to get
people to participate. So this is some
data from a project

that we're working on here at
Stanford with Dan Boneh and two CS students here, where
we're putting together

all of the voting data from
DAOs that are on Ethereum. And so this is preliminary.

I want to stress, we're not
done with the project yet. Eventually, it'll
be a live dashboard that you can check
out if you want.

But what's already
emerging from this data is exactly what we already
know from experience in the space, which is that
it's hard to get people to vote,

and most people don't vote. So what I'm showing
you here, these bars are of all the tokens
outstanding in each

of these DAOs. How many on average are
used to vote on any given proposal in the DAO.

And even those like wide bars
at the top, which are complete outliers and actually
projects I'm not personally familiar with,
even those wide bars out there

are under 30%, which
is significantly worse than basically any major
democracy in the physical world,

even though we often
complain about low turnout in the physical world. And you'll see, most of them
are like rounding errors.

I played with-- we could
have used logs or something, but I just wanted
to make it clear that the levels here
are really small.

And major, major projects
are way at the bottom here. Maker. I mean, that's a huge deal.

Tiny, tiny voting rate. And so if very few
people are voting,

that has a lot of
potential downsides. So like for one thing, in terms
of aggregating information

to make the best possible
decision by voting, it's obviously bad if the
vast majority of people aren't voting. And, of course,
it makes it harder

to sustain the idea that this is
a collectively governed entity,

and not something that's managed
by a small number of people. And so for a wide
variety of reasons,

this has become an
important area of study. How do we get
participation to go up?

So I want to talk about a
specific example of this and some of the
interesting things that are going on with it.

So Maker, one of the
very largest DAOs by TVL, one of the oldest
DAOs, one of the most

creative with its
governance, in many ways, an inspiration for the
space, in general, also,

the first special
place in my heart. It was the first DAO
that I spent time studying and hanging out with.

And it's a super, super
interesting organization that's done a lot of really
thoughtful things on governance.

So what have they done
over time in this vein of resisting censorship? Well, they started out in a way
a lot of projects now start out.

They were one of the first
to explore this model. First, they had a foundation. And the foundation directed
things and paid people,

and got things done. And then over time,
as it of took off, they dissolved the foundation.

And they're now
isn't a foundation. And things in some genuine sense
are driven by the community.

And they had this super
interesting model, which they're now changing in
interesting ways, around what

they called core units. And so people could come along. Hopefully, this is the
optimistic description.

Find a need that the project
had that wasn't being fulfilled. Propose a new core
unit of people

to fulfill that
need to work on it, and a budget, how
much they would need to be paid to do
that, and get approved,

and actually go do it. And so in some
sense, the community really did drive the
bus and still is today.

However, there's been a
bunch of challenges to that. And so Maker has really--

almost every challenge we
see in DAO governance today, Maker has already seen before. And that's why it's such an
interesting and important

project. And so what are some
of the problems? Well, when you create a super
decentralized process, where

anyone can come and form a
team and propose to get funded, it's very natural,
whether or not

the money is being
spent prudently. It's just natural
for people to start worrying that it's not because
you're not around all the time.

You don't feel it and you start
to worry that a lot of waste is going on. And so one of the things that
the Maker community has really

battled over is all
this spending justified. Or are we burning our money?

And should we have
fewer core units? And so that's been a big
debate that's been going on. The second thing which
goes back to that graph

is that they're very aware that
the participation rates are low. And they've explored some,
I think, really smart ways

to try to improve it. And so one thing they
have been out in front on is creating an official
program of delegation.

So they recognize that
basically, direct democracy is not practical, for the
reasons I said before. So let's have delegates,
and let's pay them.

And the Maker delegates get
paid quite a significant amount of money to be full-time
governance experts, if you will.

And so that might help with
the participation problem. Of course, you still need
to get the average user to pay enough
attention to delegate,

which is its own challenge. But it seems like a step
in the right direction. Another thing they've
explored, and which

I've done some research on, I
just want to mention briefly, is another thing you
could do, taking advantage of the token structure,
is actually provide

direct rewards for voting. And that's something that
more projects are now exploring in the space
and something I'm

really interested in studying. So we propose a
particular mechanism to set the price at which
you reward people to vote.

And some projects are
trying to implement that. And I'm super curious
to see if it'll work. It seems like something
at least worth trying,

given that we would like to
get the participation rates up. The second purpose is to
stimulate user demand,

is to get people excited. There's a wide range
of applications, where to be able
to say to people

if you come and join this
community or you buy this token or whatever, you get to be
a participant, a contributor

to the decisions we
make as a collective. That can be very
appealing to people. Of course, the counterargument--

I mean, there's two
counterarguments. One would be, what
I said before, that it's hard to
participate, and people don't like it all the time.

Sometimes they just want
to enjoy the service. And the second
counterargument would be, there can be lip
service paid to this idea

that you're part
of the community. But if you're only one vote
among many, what contribution you're really making? And so there's like
a challenge here

in terms of getting this right
and making people genuinely feel bought into the community.

But if you can do it,
I think it's a very-- it can be a very
powerful phenomenon. And we've seen that in quite a
few projects, where you create

this governance flywheel, by
which I mean some people start this thing.

Maybe it's a group
of friends, or people who've met each other
online in various ways, and they get really into it.

And they create a system that
makes new people want to join. And those people join
and discover, wow,

this is actually-- it is
fun to actually be part of the decision-making process. And then they come up
with new stuff to do.

Maybe they fund
some new projects that make the community
even more appealing. And then more people want to
come in and do the same thing.

And you rinse and repeat that. And that's like a thing
that a lot of people are trying to achieve
through governance,

but it's actually--
it's very nuanced. It's hard to get
that off the ground. Sometimes it seems to
happen by pure luck. How can you bottle
that and repeat it?

is like a big question, I
think, in DAO governance. Perhaps, the most
famous example of this

is Nouns, where it's like in
some sense, this arbitrary thing where each day
you have the opportunity

to bid in an auction for
a Noun, if you win it, you become a voting
member of this thing.

One Noun comes out each day. And very early on, it
created this really cool

snowball effect, where
people were like, this is a really cool community. I want to be part of this. And then it's-- the flywheel
really started to spin

because the Nouns
became quite expensive, which meant that there's now
this large treasury that this

community is in charge of, which
makes a new people want to. So then, a lot of interesting
stuff gets funded.

And that makes new people want
to come in and be part of that because there's something
real going on here. And so Nouns is probably the
single most salient example

of this, but there are,
of course, lots of others. And Nouns, for example,
they've released, basically,

the whole governance
tooling of Noun, so you can fork it and do
whatever you want with it. And there's lots of
interesting stuff

being built on top of Nouns. So it's a great example of this. The last one is the
broadest motivation,

and I would say is the
closest to the history of corporate governance. And this idea that
by having something

governed by the people who've
invested in it, by having something governed by the people
who are contributing to it,

you're creating what
we, in Social Science, would call credible commitments. You're able to promise
that in the future,

this project is going
to make decisions, consistent with the interests
of the people who are empowered

to be part of its governance. And that can be very valuable. Think about what's going
on with Apple today,

where some developers now
are reluctant to start putting in a lot of effort to
make something new for the App

Store. Obviously, people
are still doing it. It's necessary. But people on the margin
are reluctant because they

don't know what's going
to happen in the future. Are the rules going to change? So my apps aren't
allowed anymore? Are the fees going to go up?

Am I going to be allowed
to process payments the way I want to and so forth? On the margin, those
are all bad features

for long-term
innovation in a market. And if you can create
instead a model

where you say, decisions we
make in the future about how this thing works,
about the rules, about who's allowed to
develop on this thing,

about how fees are,
those are going to be made through a process
that includes all of you. You're going to be
part of the decision.

That's a way to create what
we call a credible commitment. That's a way for
you to trust now that five years from
now, your interests

are still going to be
aligned with this protocol. And so that's potentially
very powerful.

If you set it up right,
and things go well. It's still obviously hard. And so you have to decide
who are the stakeholders who

I need to be part of
this governance system so that they feel
like in the long run, their interests are
being represented.

And then you have to decide how
to represent their interests. I just want to give you
two examples of this,

and then I'll wrap up with
some more concrete discussions of how to actually do all
these things in practice.

So two really great examples
that are top of mind for me and two projects where
I've been spending

a lot of my time
studying lately, one is Lido, which I believe
is now larger than Maker.

So it's huge TVL, a new
from a DAO perspective.

So it's plugging into to
proof of stake on Ethereum. And people are worried,
and have been for some time

now since Ethereum,
since the merge, that Lido has become
too big, in the sense

that too large of a fraction
of all the staking in Ethereum is going through this
intermediate protocol,

that people are
worried about that. And that it's creating--
it's not really all the way to a single
point of failure,

but there's a concern that
there's like a concentrated risk with Lido. And so that's a
problem for Lido.

Obviously, it's a problem for
the community if it's true. If some people debate
whether it's true or not, I don't know enough to
make any claims there.

But the fact that
it could be true or that people believe
it could be true is itself a problem, not only
for the community at large

but for Lido,
specifically, because Lido wants to exist into
the future and succeed. And if people don't trust
it, then that's bad for it.

So how can they use governance
to try to solve this problem? It comes back to exactly
what I just said.

It's about bringing into
the governance process the people whose incentives
you need to align.

And so in particular, what
Lido is working on now-- and you can go check
this out in their forums. It's quite interesting.

You can see a post that I
wrote there with Porter.

What are they trying to do? They're going to try. Instead of having just a normal
token-based DAO governance

model, they're going to
take that normal model, and they're going to add
to it a new veto that

can be triggered by people
who hold staked Eth, which is the thing Lido issues
to people when they lock up

their Eth with Lido. And so they're calling
it dual governance. It's almost like--
in American politics,

we might almost call
it like bicameralism or divided government
or separation of powers. And what's the idea?

The idea is that if a
bunch of staked Eth people, whose interests are to make sure
that the proof of stake system

continues operating,
can block decisions that the LDO holders make.

Then that might assure
them in the future that the LDO holders
can't do something

overly malicious to the Ethereum
proof of stake system at large. So it's a way to create
trust by bringing

in the people who you
need to trust you directly into your governance model.

Super, super interesting. There's a lot of design
consideration of how you actually make the veto work.

So this is not nearly
a finished thing, but it's a very, very
interesting direction, I think.

The last example I
want to talk about is actually a combination
of several of these goals. It's both about, I think,
building trust, and also getting

people to come into your
community, and that's optimism. And so optimism is a layer too. And what they have
thought about--

and this is a problem that's
been around for a while. It's something Vitalik has
been super outspoken about. What's on their
mind is this idea

that if all decisions
that you put to a DAO, all the things
that can't be ossified

are done through
token voting, then you're really heavily weighting
the interests of a pretty small

set of large token holders. And that can be bad if what
